docs.title: DataFun Toolkit
docs.text:
The DataFun Toolkit provides privacy-safe utility helpers for data analytics Python projects.

This package is designed to be:

  • Imported, not modified
  • Safe to log and share
  • Consistent across operating systems

It supports common needs such as:

  • Finding the project root reliably
  • Sanitizing file paths for logs
  • Detecting runtime environment details (OS, shell, Python)
  • Emitting standardized log headers

docs.title: Who This Is For
docs.text:
• Those learning Python for data analytics
  • Debugging
  • Analytics projects that need lightweight diagnostics
  • CI / GitHub Actions environments

This toolkit intentionally avoids:

  • Heavy dependencies
  • Framework assumptions
  • User-specific identifiers

docs.title: Design Principles
docs.text:
• CI-friendly: behaves the same locally and in GitHub Actions
  • Privacy-safe: avoids usernames, hostnames, and absolute home paths
  • Teaching-first: clear structure, readable output, predictable behavior
  • Industry-legible: follows standard Python logging and packaging practices

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
pip install datafun-toolkit

Or with uv:

uv add datafun-toolkit
uv sync

Once installed, import the functions by module (see api.md).

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text:
This page documents the public API of the datafun-toolkit package.

Only the documented functions below are considered stable.

docs.title: datafun_toolkit.paths
docs.text: Utilities for locating the project root and sanitizing paths.

docs.title: find_project_root(start: Path | None = None) -> Path
docs.text:
Return the project root directory.

The project root is identified as the nearest parent directory containing either:

  • pyproject.toml, or
  • a .git directory

WHY: - Prevents hard-coded paths - Works regardless of current working directory - Behaves the same locally and in CI

Example:

from datafun_toolkit.paths import find_project_root
root = find_project_root()

docs.title: safe_relpath_str(path: Path, root: Path) -> str
docs.text:
Return a sanitized, repo-relative path string when possible.

If the path cannot be made relative to the project root, the function returns only the filename.

WHY: - Avoids leaking full home directory paths in logs - Keeps log output short and shareable

Example:

from pathlib import Path
from datafun_toolkit.paths import find_project_root, safe_relpath_str

root = find_project_root()
safe_path = safe_relpath_str(Path.cwd(), root)

docs.title: datafun_toolkit.diagnostics
docs.text: Lightweight environment detection helpers.

docs.title: detect_shell() -> str
docs.text:
Attempt to identify the active shell or terminal in a privacy-safe way.

Possible return values include: - pwsh - powershell - bash - zsh - unknown

OBS: - This function uses environment-variable heuristics only.

docs.title: detect_os() -> str
docs.text:
Return a concise operating system description.

Example output:

Windows 11
Linux 6.6
Darwin 23.1

docs.title: detect_python() -> str
docs.text: Return the active Python version string.

docs.title: datafun_toolkit.logger
docs.text: Standardized logging helpers.

docs.title: get_logger(project_name: str, *, level: str = "INFO") -> logging.Logger
docs.text:
Return a configured Python logger that:

  • Logs to both console and file
  • Avoids duplicate handlers
  • Uses consistent formatting

OBS: - The log file is created at the project root.

docs.title: log_header(logger: logging.Logger, project_name: str) -> None
docs.text:
Emit a standardized, privacy-safe run header.

The header includes: - project name - repository directory name - python version - operating system - shell - current working directory (sanitized) - whether running in GitHub Actions

OBS: - Intended to be called once per run.

docs.title: py.typed
docs.text:
This package includes a py.typed marker file as defined by PEP 561.

WHY: - Type checkers (Pyright, Mypy) only trust inline type hints in installed packages when this marker is present.

OBS: - The file may be empty; comments are allowed.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Typical usage patterns for the DataFun Toolkit.

These examples assume the package is installed and imported.

docs.title: Example: Logging a Run Header
docs.text:
from datafun_toolkit.logger import get_logger, log_header

logger = get_logger("datafun-project", level="INFO")
log_header(logger, "datafun-project")

logger.info("Starting analysis...")

Example output (sanitized):

=== RUN START ===
project=datafun-project
repo_dir=datafun-project
python=3.12.1
os=Windows 11
shell=pwsh
cwd=src
github_actions=False

docs.title: Example: Safe Path Logging
docs.text:
from pathlib import Path
from datafun_toolkit.paths import find_project_root, safe_relpath_str

root = find_project_root()
print(f"Working directory: {safe_relpath_str(Path.cwd(), root)}")

docs.title: Example: Environment Diagnostics
docs.text:
from datafun_toolkit.diagnostics import detect_shell, detect_os, detect_python

print(detect_shell())
print(detect_os())
print(detect_python())

OBS: - This information is safe to paste into issue reports or grading feedback.

docs.title: When to Use This Toolkit
docs.text:
Use it when you want: - predictable logging output - CI-safe diagnostics - consistent behavior across different machines

Do not use it for: - performance benchmarking - security auditing - deep system inspection

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common questions and issues when using datafun_toolkit.

docs.title: Why does the log file appear in the project root?
docs.text:
This is intentional.

WHY: - Makes logs easy to find - Keeps paths consistent across machines - Avoids writing to user-specific locations

docs.title: Why do logs not show usernames or full paths?
docs.text:
This toolkit intentionally sanitizes output.

WHY: - Protect privacy - Make logs safe to share publicly - Reduce noise in grading and debugging

docs.title: Why does detect_shell() return "unknown"?
docs.text:
Shell detection is heuristic.

OBS: - Some terminals do not expose identifying environment variables. - In these cases, returning "unknown" is expected and acceptable.

docs.title: Does this toolkit collect or transmit data?
docs.text:
No.

OBS: - All functions run locally and return strings only. - No network calls, telemetry, or persistent identifiers are used.
